Model: Climate Prediction Center, Leaky Bucket Model 0 - 160cm
Description: The CPC Leaky Bucket soil moisture product is a one-layer bucket water balance model. Model parameters are constant spatially and tuned to reproduce runoff of several small river basins in eastern Oklahoma.
Data Access: Climate Prediction Center (n.d.). Climate Prediction Center, Leaky Bucket Model. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from ftp://ftp.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/GIS/USDM_Products/soil/percentile/daily/

Model: Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment  Rootzone Soil Moisture (variable depth)
Description: The GRACE rootzone soil moisture model leverages a numerical model of land surface water and energy processes along with observations of terrestrial water storage (derived from observations of gravity) from the GRACE-FO satellite to estimate moisture.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Weekly data, <1 week data latency, 0.125 degree resolution
Data Access: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, National Drought Mitigation Center (n.d.). Groundwater and Soil Moisture Conditions from GRACE-FO Data Assimilation for the Contiguous U.S. And Global Land. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from https://nasagrace.unl.edu/data/

Model: North American Land Data Assimilation System (NLDAS-2) Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) 0–100cm
Description: The NLDAS-2 VIC land surface model uses three soil layers, with thicknesses that vary spatially and a two-layer energy balance snow model forced by the hourly NLDAS-2 forcing data.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Hourly data (first hour of each day used here), <1 week data latency, 0.125 degree resolution
Data Access: National Aeronautics and Space Administration Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC) (n.d.). NLDAS-2 VIC data. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from https://hydro1.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/NLDAS/NLDAS_VIC0125_H.2.0/
Reference(s): Liang et al. 1994; Wood et al. 1997

Model: North American Land Data Assimilation System (NLDAS-2) Mosaic 0–100cm
Description: The NLDAS-2 MOSAIC land surface model uses three soil layers with thicknesses of 10, 30 and 160 cm and accounts for the sub-grid heterogeneity of vegetation and soil moisture with a tiling approach.  The model is forced by the hourly NLDAS-2 forcing data.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Hourly data (first hour of each day used here), <1 week data latency, 0.125 degree resolution
Data Access: National Aeronautics and Space Administration Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC) (n.d.). NLDAS-2 MOSAIC data. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from https://hydro1.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/NLDAS/NLDAS_MOS0125_H.2.0/

Model: North American Land Data Assimilation System (NLDAS-2) Noah 0–100cm
Description: The NLDAS-2 NOAH land surface model uses four soil layers, with spatially invariant thicknesses of 10, 30, 60 and 100 cm and simulates the soil freeze-thaw process and its impact on soil heating/cooling and transpiration. The model is forced by the hourly NLDAS-2 forcing data.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Hourly data (first hour of each day used here), <1 week data latency, 0.125 degree resolution
Data Access: National Aeronautics and Space Administration Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC) (n.d.). NLDAS-2 NOAH data. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from https://hydro1.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/NLDAS/NLDAS_NOAH0125_H.2.0/
Reference(s): Chen et al. 1996; Ek et al. 2003

Model: North American Land Data Assimilation System (NLDAS-2) 0-100cm Ensemble
Description: Time and site specific mean (ensamble) soil moisture from the NLDAS-2 VIC, NLDAS-2 MOSAIC and NLDAS-2 NOAH models.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Hourly data (first hour of each day used here), <1 week data latency, 0.125 degree resolution

Model: Soil Moisture Active Passive L4 (SMAP L4) rootzone (0-100cm) soil moisture
Description: SMAP L4 soil moisture utilizes earth observations from the SMAP probe (land surface microwave emission at 1.41 GHz) in conjunction with a land surface model to estimate rootzone soil moisture.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Three hourly data (first hour of each day used here), <1 week data latency, 11km resolution
Data Access: Reichle, R.H., G. De Lannoy, R.D. Koster, W.T. Crow, J.S. Kimball, Q. Liu, and M. Bechtold. 2022. SMAP L4 Global 3-hourly 9 km EASE-Grid Surface and Root Zone Soil Moisture Analysis Update, Version 7. Root zone soil moisture (0-100 cm; percentile units). Boulder, Colorado USA. NASA National Snow and Ice Data Center Distributed Active Archive Center. doi:10.5067/LWJ6TF5SZRG3

Model: Short-term Prediction Research and Transition Center (SPoRT) rootzone (0–100cm) mean soil moisture
Description: The SPoRT soil moisture model estimates soil moisture using the NASA Land Information System (LIS) and a long-term run of the NLDAS-2 NOAH model. SPoRT integrates information from the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (NOAA/NESDIS VIIRS) instrument into the model, estimating near real time green vegetation fraction.
Spatiotemporal Resolution & Latency: Three hourly data (first hour of each day used here), 1-day data latency, 3km resolution
Data Access: Data Accessed Directly via NASA: J. Case, personal communication, April 3, 2023

Description: Topofire soil moisture is a single layer soil water balance model that assumes uniform vegetation and with soil water holding capacity defined by gridded soil water holding capacity from SSURGO.
Data Access: Topofire (n.d.). Topofire Daily Data. Retrieved August 1, 2023, from https://topofire.dbs.umt.edu/public_data/topofire_weather/daily_grids/

Model: Note: The NLDAS-2 SAC model was not available, and thus was not included in this analysis. Therefore, the NLDAS-2 ensemble soil moisture evaluated here represents the average soil moisture model estimates from the VIC, Mosaic and Noah models. Each of the NLDAS-2 land surface models leverages a different modeling architecture (e.g. VIC (Liang et al. 1994; Wood et al. 1997), Mosaic (Koster and Suarez 1994, 1992), and Noah (Chen et al. 1996; Ek et al. 2003)) but all use the same forcing data. Therefore differences in the performance of the various NLDAS-2 models is due to the model simulation architecture.
